what: Miscellaneous Functions and Themes in Use at Covalence Research
title: Miscellaneous Functions and Themes in Use at Covalence Research
text: covalencer contains various R functions use Covalence Research health economic modeling, literature synthesis, medical communication, just plain old data wrangling. Perhaps notably, provides access Covalence ggplot theme associated color palettes.

title: Miscellaneous Functions and Themes in Use at Covalence Research
text: can install development version covalencer GitHub using:
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pkg_install("CovalenceResearch/covalencer")

title: Miscellaneous Functions and Themes in Use at Covalence Research
text: Please note package much work progress, things likely break (deliberately deliberately). Use package risk.

title: Miscellaneous Functions and Themes in Use at Covalence Research
text: Apply theme_covalence() existing ggplot object, like theme:
code: library(ggplot2) library(covalencer)  ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = price, y = carat)) +   geom_point(aes(color = color), alpha = 0.5) +   scale_colour_covalence_discrete(palette = "complete") +   facet_wrap(vars(cut)) +   theme_covalence() ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = cut, y = color)) +   geom_tile(aes(fill = depth)) +   scale_fill_covalence_sequential() +   theme_covalence() +   theme(     panel.grid.major = element_blank()   )

what: Calculate qx column from a survfit object — calc_qx_from_surv
title: Calculate qx column from a survfit object — calc_qx_from_surv
text: function takes object resulting call survival::survfit() survival::survfit0() object calculates single-year lifetable stratum.

title: Calculate qx column from a survfit object — calc_qx_from_surv
code: calc_qx_from_surv(obj_survfit, ...)

title: Calculate qx column from a survfit object — calc_qx_from_surv
text: obj_survfit object returned call survival::survfit() survival::survfit0(). ... Additional arguments passed convert_survfit2tibble().

title: Calculate qx column from a survfit object — calc_qx_from_surv
text: tibble five columns - stratum first, reports stratum survfit object estimate belongs. second, third, fourth columns return standard life table estimates, including person-years (py), mortality rates (mx), probability death (qx).

title: Calculate qx column from a survfit object — calc_qx_from_surv
code: library(survival)  obj_surv <- Surv(time = cancer$time, event = cancer$status) obj_survfit <- survfit(obj_surv ~ sex, data = cancer) calc_qx_from_surv(obj_survfit, time_in = "days", age_max_years = 90L) #> # A tibble: 182 × 5 #>    stratum  year    py    mx    qx #>    <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 sex=1       0  86.5 0.983 0.626 #>  2 sex=1       1  21   1.14  0.681 #>  3 sex=1       2   4   0.75  0.528 #>  4 sex=1       3   1   0     0     #>  5 sex=1       4   1   0     0     #>  6 sex=1       5   1   0     0     #>  7 sex=1       6   1   0     0     #>  8 sex=1       7   1   0     0     #>  9 sex=1       8   1   0     0     #> 10 sex=1       9   1   0     0     #> # ℹ 172 more rows

what: Convert estimates from a survfit object to a tibble (dataframe) — convert_survfit2tibble
title: Convert estimates from a survfit object to a tibble (dataframe) — convert_survfit2tibble
text: function takes survfit object extracts time estimates, together number events number risk. Based user specification time units - either days years - function creates full sequence time event/risk number estimates 0 user-specified maximum age.

title: Convert estimates from a survfit object to a tibble (dataframe) — convert_survfit2tibble
code: convert_survfit2tibble(   obj_survfit,   time_in = c("days", "years"),   age_max_years = 120L )

title: Convert estimates from a survfit object to a tibble (dataframe) — convert_survfit2tibble
text: obj_survfit survfit object generated using survival::survfit() survival::survfit0(). time_in Unit time reported. Either days years. age_max_years Maximum age, years, data extrapolated. Defaults 120.

title: Convert estimates from a survfit object to a tibble (dataframe) — convert_survfit2tibble
text: tibble age_max_years + 1 rows three columns. first column, year, gives year, second, n_events number events (deaths) year, third, n_start, number risk start year.

title: Convert estimates from a survfit object to a tibble (dataframe) — convert_survfit2tibble
text: time points event takes place, number risk retained preceding time point event, number events zero. Beyond last observed time, number risk last observed time retained, events taking place.

title: Covalence colours — covalence_colours
text: Covalence brand colours, including primary colours ('lightblue', 'darkblue', 'teal', 'grey') accent colours ('red', 'green', 'purple', 'orange'). colour name prefixed "cov_" avoid confusion default R colour names.

title: Covalence colours — covalence_colours
code: covalence_colours(...)

title: Covalence colours — covalence_colours
text: ... Access specific colours

title: Covalence colours — covalence_colours
text: named vector brand colours

title: Covalence colours — covalence_colours
text: function taken 2022 blog post Meghan Hall.

title: Covalence colours — covalence_colours
code: covalence_colours("darkblue") #> <NA>  #>   NA

title: Covalence palette — covalence_palette
text: various Covalence palettes: complete palette contains brand colours. main palette contains main, mostly blue-ish, brand colours. accent palette contains additional, prominent colours.

title: Covalence palette — covalence_palette
code: covalence_palette(   ...,   palette = c("complete", "main", "accent", "rainbow_12_bit", "orange_teal",     "orange_purple", "orange_darkblue", "darkblues", "teals", "purples") )

title: Covalence palette — covalence_palette
text: ... Arguments passed . palette Palette use. One 'complete', 'main', 'accent', 'rainbow_12_bit'.

title: Covalence palette — covalence_palette
text: named vector brand colours.

title: Covalence palette — covalence_palette
text: function slightly modified 2022 blog post Meghan Hall. 12-bit rainbow palette developed Kate Morley released terms Creative Commons CC0 1.0 Universal Legal Code.

title: Covalence palette — covalence_palette
code: require(scales) #> Loading required package: scales show_col(covalence_palette(palette = "main"))

what: Function factory to generate palette — generate_pal
title: Function factory to generate palette — generate_pal
text: function generates second function, use 'ggplot' scales.

title: Function factory to generate palette — generate_pal
code: generate_pal(palette, n, reverse = FALSE)

title: Function factory to generate palette — generate_pal
text: palette Palette use. One 'complete', 'main', 'accent', 'rainbow_12_bit'. n Number colours wanted palette. reverse palette reversed? Either 'TRUE' 'FALSE'.

title: Function factory to generate palette — generate_pal
text: palette-generating function.

title: Function factory to generate palette — generate_pal
text: function slightly modified 2022 blog post Nicola Rennie.

what: Make a single-year life table from numbers of events and at risk — make_lt
title: Make a single-year life table from numbers of events and at risk — make_lt
text: description Based output convert_survfit2tibble(), make tibble containing qx (probabilities dying reaching age x+1) year.

title: Make a single-year life table from numbers of events and at risk — make_lt
code: make_lt(data)

title: Make a single-year life table from numbers of events and at risk — make_lt
text: data tibble produced convert_survfit2tibble().

title: Make a single-year life table from numbers of events and at risk — make_lt
text: tibble four columns, first year. second column, py, gives person-years spent year x.third column, mx, gives mortality rate year x; last, qx, probability dying years x x+1.

title: Make a single-year life table from numbers of events and at risk — make_lt
text: person-years (py) lived year calculated mean cohort age x age x+1, .e., deaths assumed occur, average, mid-way single-year interval. mortality rate, mx, calculated number events (deaths) per person-year. probability death ages x x+1 calculated \(q_{x} = 1 - \exp{-n*m_{x}}\), n=1 intervals single-year. implies assumption constant mortality 1-year interval.

what: Plot incremental outcomes on the cost-effectiveness plane — plot_psa_scatter
title: Plot incremental outcomes on the cost-effectiveness plane — plot_psa_scatter
text: plot_psa_scatter takes data.frame incremental quality-adjusted life-years (QALYs) incremental costs, might obtained probabilistic sensitivity analysis, plots data incremental cost-effectiveness plane.

title: Plot incremental outcomes on the cost-effectiveness plane — plot_psa_scatter
code: plot_psa_scatter(   data,   delta_qalys,   delta_costs,   currency = "$",   point_alpha = 0.4,   point_color = "#0099cc",   point_shape = 16,   point_size = 2,   point_jitter_height = 0,   point_jitter_width = 0,   plot_wtp_at = NULL,   wtp_alpha = 1,   wtp_color = "#154754",   wtp_linetype = "dashed",   wtp_linewidth = 0.5,   show_mean = TRUE,   mean_alpha = 1,   mean_color = "#7a0d66",   mean_shape = 18,   mean_size = 3 )

title: Plot incremental outcomes on the cost-effectiveness plane — plot_psa_scatter
text: data data.frame. delta_qalys Unquoted column name incremental QALYs. delta_costs Unquoted column name incremental costs. currency String currency symbol. Default $. point_alpha Numeric value point opacity. Default 0.4. point_color Point color. Default #0099cc. point_shape Integer value point shape. Default 16. See ?pch available shapes. point_size Numeric value point size. Default 2. point_jitter_height, point_jitter_width Numeric value vertical horizontal jittering. Default 0 (jittering). careful key-outcome pairs may plotted much jitter. plot_wtp_at Numeric value plot WTP threshold. default, argument NULL WTP threshold plotted. wtp_alpha Numeric value WTP threshold line opacity. Default 1. wtp_color Color WTP threshold line. Default #154754. wtp_linetype valid specification WTP threshold line type. Default dashed (2). See ggplot2 documentation valid options. wtp_linewidth Numeric value WTP threshold line width. Default 0.5. show_mean Boolean indicating mean incremental QALYs costs displayed (point). Default TRUE. mean_alpha Numeric value mean point opacity. Default 1. mean_color Color mean point. Default #7a0d66. mean_shape Integer value mean point shape. Default 18. See ?pch available shapes. mean_size Numeric value point size. Default 3.

title: Plot incremental outcomes on the cost-effectiveness plane — plot_psa_scatter
text: ggplot object.

title: Plot incremental outcomes on the cost-effectiveness plane — plot_psa_scatter
text: Fore information display incremental outcomes cost-effectiveness plane, see, example, Fenwick et al., 2006.

title: Plot incremental outcomes on the cost-effectiveness plane — plot_psa_scatter
code: library(ggplot2) df <- data.frame(   d_qalys = runif(1000, -1, 2),   d_costs = runif(1000, -1000, 10000),   country = rep(c("Country A", "Country B"), each = 500) )  # Standard plot (without WTP threshold) plot_psa_scatter(df, d_qalys, d_costs) #> No WTP threshold is plotted.   # Now with a WTP threshold of 20,000 plot_psa_scatter(df, d_qalys, d_costs, plot_wtp_at = 20000) #> The WTP threshold is plotted at #> $20000 per QALY gained.   # Facet plot by adding a call to facet_plot/facet_grid plot_psa_scatter(df, d_qalys, d_costs, plot_wtp_at = 20000) +   facet_wrap(vars(country)) #> The WTP threshold is plotted at #> $20000 per QALY gained.   # Don't forget that column names should be unquoted if (FALSE) { plot_psa_scatter(df, "d_qalys", "d_costs") }

what: Plot summary of RoB2 assessments — plot_rob2_summary
title: Plot summary of RoB2 assessments — plot_rob2_summary
text: RoB2 tool, developed Cochrane Collaboration, allows assessing risk bias randomized trials. addition study-level traffic light plot, typical output RoB2 assessments summary proportion studies specific bias risk, per domain. latter type plot created plot_rob2_summary, requires summarized data (.e., data synthesis calculations performed function).

title: Plot summary of RoB2 assessments — plot_rob2_summary
code: plot_rob2_summary(data, domain, judgement, study_share)

title: Plot summary of RoB2 assessments — plot_rob2_summary
text: data data.frame. domain Unquoted column name bias domains. judgement Unquoted column name risk bias judgement. study_share Unquoted column name proportion [0, 1] studies specific bias risk per domain. Values column must numeric.

title: Plot summary of RoB2 assessments — plot_rob2_summary
text: ggplot2 object

title: Plot summary of RoB2 assessments — plot_rob2_summary
code: library(ggplot2)  data_rob2 <- data.frame(   domain = rep(     c(       "Overall bias",       "Bias due to deviations from intended interventions",       "Missing data"     ),     each = 3   ),   judgement = rep(c("Low", "Some concerns", "High risk of bias"), times = 3),   study_share = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.2, 0.1, 0.85, 0.05, 0.2, 0.5, 0.3) )  plot_rob2_summary(   data_rob2,   domain = domain,   judgement = judgement,   study_share = study_share ) #> Warning: There was 1 warning in `dplyr::mutate()`. #> ℹ In argument: `plot_domain = forcats::fct_relevel(...)`. #> Caused by warning: #> ! 3 unknown levels in `f`: Bias in selection of reported results, Bias in outcome #> measurement, and Bias arising from randomisation process

what: Discrete colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_discrete
title: Discrete colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_discrete
text: scale_*_covalence_discrete functions provide discrete scales Covalence colours use ggplot2 plots.

title: Discrete colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_discrete
code: scale_colour_covalence_discrete(palette = "complete", reverse = FALSE)  scale_color_covalence_discrete(palette = "complete", reverse = FALSE)  scale_fill_covalence_discrete(palette = "complete", reverse = FALSE)

title: Discrete colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_discrete
text: palette Palette use. One 'complete', 'main', 'accent', 'rainbow_12_bit'. reverse palette reversed? Either 'TRUE' 'FALSE'.

title: Discrete colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_discrete
text: Discrete colour/fill scales ggplot2.

title: Discrete colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_discrete
text: functions inspired 2022 blog post Nicola Rennie.

title: Discrete colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_discrete
code: library(ggplot2)  ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price)) +   geom_point(aes(colour = cut), alpha = 0.4) +   scale_colour_covalence_discrete(palette = "complete") +   theme_covalence()   ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = price)) +   geom_histogram(aes(fill = cut)) +   scale_fill_covalence_discrete(     palette = "rainbow_12_bit",     reverse = TRUE   ) +   theme_covalence() #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

what: Diverging colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_diverging
title: Diverging colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_diverging
text: scale_*_covalence_diverging functions provide diverging scales Covalence colours use ggplot2 plots.

title: Diverging colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_diverging
code: scale_colour_covalence_diverging(   palette = "orange_teal",   reverse = FALSE,   midpoint = 0,   na_colour = "#cccccc" )  scale_color_covalence_diverging(   palette = "orange_teal",   reverse = FALSE,   midpoint = 0,   na_colour = "#cccccc" )  scale_fill_covalence_diverging(   palette = "orange_teal",   reverse = FALSE,   midpoint = 0,   na_colour = "#cccccc" )

title: Diverging colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_diverging
text: palette One diverging colour palettes (orange_teal, orange_purple, orange_darkblue). Default orange_teal). reverse palette reversed? Either 'TRUE' 'FALSE'. midpoint Numeric value midpoint. Default 0. na_colour Colour missing values. Default "#cccccc" (grey80).

title: Diverging colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_diverging
text: Diverging colour/fill scales ggplot2.

title: Diverging colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_diverging
text: functions inspired 2022 blog post Cara Thompson.

title: Diverging colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_diverging
code: library(ggplot2)

what: Sequential colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_sequential
title: Sequential colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_sequential
text: scale_*_covalence_sequential functions provide sequential scales Covalence colours use ggplot2 plots.

title: Sequential colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_sequential
code: scale_colour_covalence_sequential(   palette = "darkblues",   reverse = FALSE,   na_colour = "#cccccc" )  scale_color_covalence_sequential(   palette = "darkblues",   reverse = FALSE,   na_colour = "#cccccc" )  scale_fill_covalence_sequential(   palette = "darkblues",   reverse = FALSE,   na_colour = "#cccccc" )

title: Sequential colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_sequential
text: palette One sequential colour palettes (darkblues, teals, purples). Default darkblues). reverse palette reversed? Either 'TRUE' 'FALSE'. na_colour Colour missing values. Default "#cccccc" (grey80).

title: Sequential colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_sequential
text: Sequential colour/fill scales ggplot2.

title: Sequential colour and fill scales for ggplot2 — scale_colour_covalence_sequential
code: library(ggplot2)  ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = cut, y = carat)) +   geom_point(aes(colour = price)) +   scale_colour_covalence_sequential() +   theme_covalence()   ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = cut, y = color)) +   geom_tile(aes(fill = depth)) +   scale_fill_covalence_sequential(palette = "teals") +   theme_covalence() +   theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank())

what: Calculate the mean of two variables — stat_doublemean
title: Calculate the mean of two variables — stat_doublemean
text: Calculate arithmetic mean two variables, x y, subsequent use call geom_point().

title: Calculate the mean of two variables — stat_doublemean
code: stat_doublemean(   mapping = NULL,   data = NULL,   geom = "point",   position = "identity",   na.rm = FALSE,   show.legend = NA,   inherit.aes = TRUE,   ... )

title: Calculate the mean of two variables — stat_doublemean
text: mapping Set aesthetic mappings created aes(). specified inherit.aes = TRUE (default), combined default mapping top level plot. must supply mapping plot mapping. data data displayed layer. three options: NULL, default, data inherited plot data specified call ggplot(). data.frame, object, override plot data. objects fortified produce data frame. See fortify() variables created. function called single argument, plot data. return value must data.frame, used layer data. function can created formula (e.g. ~ head(.x, 10)). geom geometric object use display data, either ggproto Geom subclass string naming geom stripped geom_ prefix (e.g. "point" rather "geom_point") position Position adjustment, either string naming adjustment (e.g. "jitter" use position_jitter), result call position adjustment function. Use latter need change settings adjustment. na.rm FALSE, default, missing values removed warning. TRUE, missing values silently removed. show.legend logical. layer included legends? NA, default, includes aesthetics mapped. FALSE never includes, TRUE always includes. can also named logical vector finely select aesthetics display. inherit.aes FALSE, overrides default aesthetics, rather combining . useful helper functions define data aesthetics inherit behaviour default plot specification, e.g. borders(). ... arguments passed layer(). often aesthetics, used set aesthetic fixed value, like colour = "red" size = 3. may also parameters paired geom/stat.

title: Calculate the mean of two variables — stat_doublemean
text: 'ggplot2' stat.

title: Calculate the mean of two variables — stat_doublemean
text: code stat layer heavily based extending ggplot2 vignette.

title: Calculate the mean of two variables — stat_doublemean
code: library(ggplot2)  ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price)) +   geom_point() +   stat_doublemean(color = "#0099cc", shape = 18, size = 3)

what: The default Covalence ggplot2 theme — theme_covalence
title: The default Covalence ggplot2 theme — theme_covalence
text: theme provides defaults required generate plots, using ggplot2, aligned Covalence Research house style. theme can modified using theme(). Also consider using various colour palettes ensure house style met.

title: The default Covalence ggplot2 theme — theme_covalence
code: theme_covalence(   base_size = 12,   base_family = "sans",   strip_bg_colour = "#FFFFFF",   strip_text_colour = "#326aa0",   ... )

title: The default Covalence ggplot2 theme — theme_covalence
text: base_size Base font size, points. Default 12. base_family Base font family. Default "sans". strip_bg_colour colour fill strip backgrounds. Default #326aa0. strip_text_colour colour strip labels. Default #FFFFFF (white). ... Additional arguments passed theme

title: The default Covalence ggplot2 theme — theme_covalence
text: ggplot2 theme object.

title: The default Covalence ggplot2 theme — theme_covalence
code: library(ggplot2)  ggplot(data = msleep, aes(x = brainwt, y = bodywt)) +   geom_point() +   theme_covalence() #> Warning: Removed 27 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).   ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = price, y = carat)) +   geom_point(colour = covalence_colours("cov_lightblue"), alpha = 0.4) +   facet_wrap(vars(cut)) +   theme_covalence()
